title: Web APIs with R
text:
Welcome
This is the website for the work-in-progress book, Web APIs with R. This book will teach you how to create and utilize web APIs in R.
This website is free to use, and is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.
The code contained in this book is simultaneously available under the MIT license; this means that you are free to use it in your own packages, as long as you cite the source.

title: Web APIs with R
text:
Want to help?
I am writing this book in a GitHub repository. Follow the “Edit this page” or “Report an issue” links in the table of contents if you would like to help!

title: Web APIs with R
text:
The R4DS Online Learning Community
If you would like to discuss the contents of this book (or any other R-related topic), join the R4DS Online Learning Community Slack.

title: Web APIs with R
text:
Code of Conduct
Please note that Web APIs with R is released with a Contributor Code of Conduct. By contributing to this project, you agree to abide by its terms.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.1 Who should read this book?
This might overlap with the “What will I learn?” section. It feels like a good thing to have up front to entice people to read or buy the book, though.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.2 What will I learn?
Describe the overall goals, and explain the learning objective hierarchy. Maybe this is before or instead of who should read?

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.3 What won’t I learn?
I like the idea of this section, but I don’t know if it will fit.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.4 How is this book organized?
I’d love to know!

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.5 What should I already know?
Describe what we expect people to already know. Include references to other books: R4DS, AdvR, RPkgs, Do4DS, maybe MShiny. Note that each part and/or chapter will describe the prerequisites for that part.

title: 1  Introduction
section: 1.6 How do I run the code?
text:
1.6 How do I run the code?
Explain what code looks like here vs to the user. Give a disclaimer that open source software changes so things might change, and that we’ll try to keep the online version up-to-date. Potentially link to additional resources, maybe a book package.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.7 Acknowledgements
This is the acknowledgement that appears in the actual book. RStudio has code to auto-generate it, consider something similar.

title: 1  Introduction
text: API stands for “application programming interface,” but you will almost always see it written as “API.” It’s pronounced “A P I.”↩︎
